nodes.name: Human–robot collision in shared workspace
aliases: physical collision between robot and human
nodes.description: Potential physical contact between a robot and a nearby human that can cause harm when robots operate in the same environment.
nodes.node_rationale: Introduced in I Introduction as the primary safety concern motivating the work.

nodes.name: Inaccurate human motion prediction from fixed utility model
aliases: prediction error from rigid human model
model mismatch in human motion forecasting
nodes.description: Errors arise when the robot assumes the human will continue to optimise a learned reward, yet the human pursues unseen goals or avoids unknown obstacles.
nodes.node_rationale: Discussed in I Introduction and III-C as the main cause of unsafe plans.

nodes.name: Unaccounted robot tracking error under uncertain human motion
aliases: tracking error not considered with moving people
nodes.description: Simplified planning models ignore inertia, actuator limits and disturbances, causing the real robot to deviate from the planned path while humans move unpredictably.
nodes.node_rationale: Outlined in III-B and V-A as a separate contributor to collision risk.

nodes.name: Rationality coefficient β as indicator of model confidence in utility-based human models
nodes.description: Instead of viewing β as inherent human rationality, it can be treated as a time-varying scalar measuring how well the robot’s model explains current behaviour.
nodes.node_rationale: Introduced in IV and motivated throughout as the key insight enabling adaptive prediction.

nodes.name: Combining probabilistic human predictions with worst-case robot tracking error to bound collision probability
aliases: joint human probability and robot error bound
nodes.description: Safety can be analysed by merging a probabilistic forecast of human motion with a deterministic bound E on robot tracking error, giving an overall collision probability.
nodes.node_rationale: Formulated in V-B as the core idea behind the probabilistic safety certificate.

nodes.name: Real-time Bayesian inference of model confidence to adapt human motion predictions
nodes.description: Design principle: continuously update belief over β using observed human actions so that predictions automatically widen when the model performs poorly and narrow when accurate.
nodes.node_rationale: Section IV-A proposes this approach to mitigate prediction inaccuracies.

nodes.name: Probabilistic safety certificate using max marginal collision probability and FaSTrack bound
nodes.description: Design principle: approximate trajectory-wide collision probability by the worst instantaneous marginal, combined with tracking error bound E, to enable real-time rejection of unsafe plans.
nodes.node_rationale: Explained in V-B as the key planning strategy.

nodes.name: Hidden Markov model inference over discrete β values
nodes.description: Implements the Bayesian confidence inference by maintaining a belief over ~10 log-spaced β hypotheses and smoothing it over time for tractability.
nodes.node_rationale: Detailed in IV-A; enables real-time confidence updating.

nodes.name: FaSTrack tracking error bound integration with Minkowski collision set
nodes.description: Pre-computes a set E guaranteeing that the physical robot stays within E of the planned state, allowing collision checking via the Minkowski sum HE(xR).
nodes.node_rationale: Section V-A and V-B provide the mechanism for worst-case tracking consideration.

nodes.name: Online planner with node rejection based on collision probability threshold
nodes.description: During search, any candidate state whose marginal collision probability exceeds a designer-chosen threshold (e.g., 1%) is pruned, ensuring generated trajectories satisfy the certificate.
nodes.node_rationale: Described in V-C as the practical online planning procedure.

nodes.name: Simulation results: adaptive β improves safety distance and efficiency
nodes.description: Across 48 human trajectories, adaptive β inference kept larger minimum distances and reduced travel time compared with fixed-β baselines.
nodes.node_rationale: Reported in VI Demonstration with Real Human Trajectories.

nodes.name: Hardware demonstration of quadcopter avoiding humans
nodes.description: A Crazyflie 2.0 quadcopter navigated around a walking person indoors using the full pipeline, avoiding collisions in all recorded videos.
nodes.node_rationale: Mentioned in VI Demonstration and linked video.

nodes.name: Deploy real-time Bayesian β inference for human motion prediction during robot operation
nodes.description: Implement the HMM-based Bayesian update over discrete β values at runtime, widening or narrowing human-motion predictions in real time.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Algorithm runs continuously during operation (V-C Safe Online Planning) – deployment phase.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Validated in simulation and limited hardware demos (VI Demonstration) – prototype/pilot maturity.
nodes.node_rationale: Directly addresses prediction inaccuracy by adapting confidence.

nodes.name: Integrate confidence-aware human predictions with FaSTrack-based probabilistic safety planning
nodes.description: Combine adaptive human prediction, FaSTrack tracking bound, max-marginal collision approximation and node-rejection rule to generate robot trajectories that satisfy a predefined collision-probability threshold.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Algorithm executes online as the robot plans and tracks (V-C) – deployment phase.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Shown to work in hardware demo but not yet at large-scale deployment (VI Demonstration).
nodes.node_rationale: Implements the full safety certificate ensuring collisions remain below acceptable probability.
